meta.name: LSRL Interpretation
meta.subject: AP Statistics
meta.skill: Interpret slope, y-intercept, and correlation coefficient in context
meta.description: Students write contextual interpretations of regression output

meanings.E: Essentially Correct - all key elements present
meanings.P: Partially Correct - some key elements missing
meanings.I: Incorrect - major errors or missing mandatory elements

perField.slope:
Sentence Frame:
"For every increase of 1 [x-unit], the predicted [y-variable] increases/decreases by [slope] [y-units], on average."

Key elements: prediction language, direction, slope value, both variables, units, "on average"
perField.intercept:
Sentence Frame:
"When [x-variable] is 0 [x-units], the predicted [y-variable] is [intercept] [y-units]."

OR if x=0 is not meaningful:
"The y-intercept has no meaningful interpretation because [reason: x=0 is impossible or outside the data range]."
perField.correlation:
Sentence Frame:
"There is a [weak/moderate/strong], [positive/negative], linear relationship between [x-variable] and [y-variable]."

Strength guide: |r| < 0.5 = weak, 0.5-0.8 = moderate, > 0.8 = strong

hints.paragraphFrame:
Paragraph Frame:

"For every increase of 1 [x-unit], the predicted [y-variable] increases/decreases by [slope] [y-units], on average. When [x-variable] is 0 [x-units], the predicted [y-variable] is [intercept] [y-units]. (Or: The y-intercept has no meaningful interpretation because...) There is a [weak/moderate/strong], [positive/negative], linear relationship between [x-variable] and [y-variable]."
